urn:contentItem:60VS-KD61-JDVS-12D2-00000-00Aussie Regulator Refuses To Back Down After Facebook News Warning2020-09-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:17:44ZLexisNexisAussie Regulator Refuses To Back Down After Facebook News WarningTom Jowitt

Blunt warning from Facebook about blocking news sharing down under, receives equally blunt response from antitrust officials

Australian officials have refused to back down after Facebook threatened to block news sharing down under if a proposed law is approved.

Earlier this month, Facebook had warned local politicians it would prevent Facebook users in Australia from sharing local and international news, if Australia presses ahead with new legislation.

Australia is proposing new laws that will require companies such as Facebook, to pay media outlets for the use of their news content.

Blunt warning

Facebook's warning to Australian users had been made by Will Easton, MD of Facebook Australia & New Zealand in a hard hitting and blunt blog post.

Easton said that Australia was drafting a new regulation that "misunderstands the dynamics of the internet and will do damage to the very news organisations the government is trying to protect."

Easton accused the commission overseeing the process of ignoring important facts, and the law "defies logic and will hurt, not help, the long-term vibrancy of Australia's news and media sector."

Facebook's Easton also said the proposed law was effectively bad legislation.

Google has also expressed its opposition to this Australia legislation and used its search web page in Australia to warn local users that it would harm their ability to search.

Blunt response

But Australian officials had an equally blunt response to Facebook's managing director in Australia and New Zealand, telling Facebook "'it's their call' to block news content.

Reuters quoted Australia's top antitrust regulator as saying on Thursday that Facebook will be "weakened" if it stops Australians from sharing news so the company can avoid paying for content.

"It would be a shame for Australian democracy (and) it would be a shame for Facebook users if they took that course of action," ACCC Chair Rod Sims reportedly said in a speech delivered via Zoom.

"It would also weaken Facebook, so it's their call," he added. "If people can't get their news from Facebook then they'll go elsewhere to get their news."

Sims said no model to solve this problem had been effective so far.

Sims reportedly said Australia's plan was not a tax on Big Tech or a subsidy for other companies, saying it was "a question of addressing a market power imbalance and one that matters to the future of our society".

"If you had a competitive market you wouldn't need this," he said.

If Facebook quit news sharing in Australia to avoid the law, the company "may get something worse" elsewhere, Sims reportedly added.

European battle

In April this year Google was instructed by the French competition authority to pay French publishers and news agencies for re-using content or news.

Google in September last year had stopped its users in France from being able to view news snippets from European publishers on search results.

That meant that French web users were only be able to see the headlines, and not the first few lines or a thumbnail image for news content, unless of course the publishers specifically gave permission for it to show previews.

That came after the European Union passed a controversial copyright law reform in March 2019.

After a long battle, the European Parliament had backed the copyright reforms that aim to close loopholes that had allowed big tech companies such as Google and Facebook to provide news from third-party sources without paying for it.

In Germany, meanwhile, Google opted to feature only content from those who agreed to provide it for free.

urn:contentItem:5WVG-H4V1-JBTY-W00N-00000-00Aussie report targets big tech's media dominance;Study highlights digital giants' effect on publishing industry, could offer blueprint for Canada2019-08-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:17:45ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A1Aussie report targets big tech's media dominanceStudy highlights digital giants' effect on publishing industry, could offer blueprint for CanadaTony Wong Toronto Star

Australia is taking on the digital behemoths of Facebook and Google, while the rest of the world watches closely. But will Canada follow?

After an 18-month landmark study, the final report from the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission on regulating big platforms and encouraging media competition was released in July. It didn't get a lot of attention outside the country initially, but it is a watershed moment for consumers in the digital era as global regulators are examining whether it provides a blueprint for the future.

It is one of the first instances where an independent regulator is looking at antitrust and competition law through the lens of consumer protection regarding digital platforms and the publishing industry.

Google and Facebook are responsible for more than 70 per cent of all digital advertising, with traditional publishers and others struggling for the remaining piece of the market. That has left a hole in local news, not just in Australia, but in other countries including Canada.

"This is the first time we've seen really a credible, independent, non-industry panel really examine the media implications and what it will cost the economy," says John Hinds, CEO of News Media Canada, which represents Canadian newspapers.

"This isn't something that can be regarded as a partisan report by the industry or something that is politicized," Hinds said. "It's looking at how the big platforms are affecting consumers and the economy through a very practical lens."

The sweeping 632-page report comes with 23 recommendations, including methods to ensure there is enough competition in the market, to determine if there is sufficient transparency in the prices charged for advertising and to require platforms to develop a code of conduct to make sure news businesses are treated fairly. News businesses would also be given notifications about any changes to algorithms that would affect news rankings on websites.

Other recommendations include taxpayer funding for local news and allowing donations for non-profit organizations engaging in public interest journalism to be tax deductible. The digital platforms have three months to respond to the report. The Australian government has said it will have a response to the report by the end of the year.

A spokesperson for the Canadian Competition Bureau said the bureau was aware of the Australian initiative to investigate digital platforms, but would not confirm whether it was considering a similar study.

"As you know, the bureau closely follows the developments of investigations by our international counterparts while remaining mindful of the different legal regimes in each jurisdiction," said spokesperson Jayme Albert in a statement to the Star. "The bureau continues to closely monitor firms in the digital economy to ensure they do not engage in anti-competitive conduct."

Local news has become an endangered species, with many smaller newspapers disappearing in the face of digital disruption. New York Times executive editor Dean Baquet said "the greatest crisis in American journalism is the death of local news" at an International News Media Association (INMA) conference. Baquet predicted that "most local newspapers in America are going to die in the next five years, except for the ones that have been bought by a billionaire."

INMA, whose board of directors includes Torstar publisher John Boynton, considers and shares global strategies for media growth.

A study released in June by the organization found that Google alone made $4.7 billion (U.S.) in 2018 from publishers through advertising linked to its search engine.

Google has denied that figure, but there's no doubt that the search engine along with Facebook takes the lion's share of the digital advertising market.

Big tech has been under major regulatory scrutiny this year, not just for the impact on legacy media, but on privacy and antitrust issues.

Facebook was recently fined $5 billion by the U.S. Federal Trade Commission over privacy breaches in the Cambridge Analytica scandal. The U.S. Justice Department has also launched a sweeping antitrust investigation into the platforms, and the European Commission in July said it was launching an antitrust investigation into the activities of Amazon. Lawmakers in the U.S. have introduced bipartisan legislation (the Journalism Competition and Preservation Act) looking at how the newspaper industry can reach an agreement with the platforms for a share of the advertising revenue, giving them a four-year window to come up with a deal.

But while the European Union and the U.S. have launched aggressive investigations into the big digital platforms, other countries, including Canada, have taken more of a wait-and-see approach. Part of the reasoning may have been that the bigger jurisdictions have greater resources to deal with the world's biggest companies.

Not so for Australia. The country of 25 million, compared to Canada's 37 million, is not only less populated, but has a smaller economy (13th largest in the world by GDP, compared to Canada's, which is 10th). But it has decided to tackle the issue head on.

"Australia, like Canada, are commodity-based economies with large land masses that are facing similar issues in regard to disruption," said Mihkel Tombak, Hatch professor of technology management and strategy at the University of Toronto and an antitrust expert.

"Canada, though, has historically been more passive and sometimes waiting for other people to take the lead. This could either be a lack of self-confidence, or maybe it's the smart thing to do. Let them experiment first and see what works."

Albert said the Canadian Competition Bureau was "unable to confirm" whether it was investigating "any specific matters with regard to the publishing industry, as the Bureau is required by law to conduct work confidentially."

News Media Canada's Hinds says he has been in touch with the bureau to try and arrange a meeting to determine next steps.

"A lot of the discussion around media is about democracy and privacy. But the Competition Bureau can look at the issue through the lens of a tangible economic perspective and that's certainly what we want," Hinds said. "What the Australian example is telling us is that while everyone is looking for a silver bullet, this is an incredibly complex issue that requires a multi-faceted approach."

What the Australian Competition Bureau didn't do was recommend the breakup of the large platforms, although it did recommended changes that would force companies to inform regulators about the impact mergers would have on competition.

"You don't necessarily want to discourage them from innovating or growing bigger, but what you want to do is to stop them from behaving badly so it stops other people from growing and innovating," U of T's Tombak said. "But the important thing is that the Australians are taking this very seriously."

One way to regulate transnational companies with global reach might be the formation of an international competition authority, similar to the World Trade Organization, Tombak said.

"It's been talked about before. But maybe now is the time, given the rise of these major digital platforms, that you need a competition regulator with more clout."

In July, competition authorities of the G7 countries and the European Commission released a common understanding agreement highlighting challenges faced by regulators in the digital economy. It's not quite the formation of a transnational competition bureau, but it's a recognition that more needs to be done.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XR7-PKM1-DYTJ-62HY-00000-00Aussie watchdog gets $27m for Google, Facebook crackdown2019-12-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:17:44ZLexisNexisBUSINESSGeneralAussie watchdog gets $27m for Google, Facebook crackdown

Australia could become the first country in the world to force digital platforms like Facebook and Google to pay for news.

READ MORE:

Aussie regulator takes Google to court, alleging it misled users over location data

Winston Peters throws support behind NZME"s bid to buy rival Stuff

NZ company must pay Facebook $800K in fake "likes" case

That prospect is being held up after Prime Minister Scott Morrison has adopted many of the reforms suggested by the ACCC"s 18-month Digital Platforms inquiry for a crackdown on Big Tech.

But it is only a prospect, giving Facebook and Google 11 months to come up with a voluntary code of practice, which could potentially head off the reforms.

The Aussie PM did agree to a request from the ACCC (Australia"s equivalent to our Commerce Commission) for a new special unit to monitor digital platforms. Morrison said the unit would get A$26.9m ($27m) in funding to undertake a series of inquiries, "starting with the supply of online advertising and ad-tech services."

The ACCC"s Digital Platforms report, focused primarily on Google and Facebook, whom it said accounted for 71c of every dollar spent on digital advertising in Australia. There was a risk that the pair"s market dominance in digital advertising was undermining media"s ability to deliver quality news, which it saw as critical to the effective functioning of democracy, the watchdog said.

It also raised concerns in a range of other areas including privacy, and Google and Facebook"s closely held algorithms and what it saw as general lack of transparency that made it hard for advertisers to gauge if they were getting "value for money."

If Facebook and Google can"t reach a voluntary code agreement in negotiations led by ACCC chairman Rod Simms, they could have to spill their ad algorithm secrets, and be compelled to share revenue from ads around content uploaded by media to the likes of Google-owned YouTube - effectively compelling Google and Facebook to pay for news content.

A proposed tightening of privacy laws would mean people will have to receive notifications about what data is being collected about them and how it"s being used, and would give them the right to erase it.

"The companies are on ­notice," said Treasurer Josh Frydenberg, who announced the reforms along with Morrison and Communications Minister Paul Fletcher.

"The government is not ­messing around, we will not hesitate to act."

However, some Big Tech critics were disappointed that the status quo would last for at least another year as the voluntary code negotiations dragged on.

And while most of the ACCC"s reforms were adopted, Morrison"s government did not take up a suggestion for tax-breaks to encourage philanthropic support for journalism, nor a recommendation for a mandatory code that would require digital platforms to detect and take down copyright-protected content.

Google and Facebook both said they support greater competition and will work closely with the ACCC.

"We support a sustainable news ecosystem which is why we work with publishers to help them reach new audiences," Mia Garlick, director of policy, Australia and New Zealand at Facebook, said in an emailed statement.

Aussie govt on front-foot, NZ on back-foot

The Digital Platforms reforms come in parallel to other enforcement action, which in general has contrasted with a more back-foot stance on this side of the Tasman.

The ACCC recently filed a Federal Court case against Google, alleging it misled consumers into thinking they had disabled location-tracking - when, in fact, the search-ad giant was still able to track every move they made. Here, the ComCom is keeping a watching brief.

The Australian government passed a tough new law in the wake of the Christchurch mosque massacres, allowing social media platforms to be fined up to 10 per cent of their revenue or their executives jailed for up to three months if they fail to remove "abhorrent violent material expeditiously."

And a "Google tax" crackdown on profit-shifting was implemented across the Tasman while our government is still weighing whether or not to introduce a similar measure.

Wait - a hint of front-foot

But our government did go on the front foot yesterday as NZ First leader and Deputy Prime Minister Winston Peters cited the social media giants" "suffocating" effect on New Zealand media companies as he throw his support behind NZME"s renewed bid to buy Stuff.

urn:contentItem:5WDH-8M31-JBV1-X0TV-00000-00Aussie watchdog readies clampdown on Google, Facebook2019-06-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:17:44ZLexisNexisAussie watchdog readies clampdown on Google, FacebookSydney, June 23 2019

Australia's competition watchdog is poised to call for far-reaching new regulations on Facebook, Google and other tech giants which could have global ramifications for how they make money and choose the content people consume.

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's recommendations, if confirmed, would be among the strongest yet in a drive to rein in the power of digital behemoths amid a host of worldwide concerns ranging from anti-trust issues to privacy abuse, and their role in spreading disinformation and hateful content.

Following an 18-month inquiry into the power of digital platforms, the ACCC is due to issue its final report by June 30.

It is expected to include proposals for sweeping controls over tech companies' handling of personal data and their use of "opaque" algorithms to rank how they display advertisements, search results and content.

In a 328-page preliminary report issued in December, the ACCC had raised alarm over the "substantial" market power wielded by the likes of Google and Facebook, and notably the "lack of transparency" in their operations.

"We are at a critical point in considering the impact of digital platforms on society," said the report, initiated by the conservative government at the behest of Australia's main media organisations.

The report focused particular attention on the huge impact Google and Facebook have had on Australia's news industry, with the number of newspaper and online journalists falling more than 20 percent since 2014 as digital advertising revenues were overwhelmingly captured by the two tech titans.

"While the ACCC recognises their significant benefits to consumers and businesses, there are important questions to be asked about the role the global digital platforms play in the supply of news and journalism in Australia," it said.

A set of preliminary proposals set out in the report, many of which are expected to figure in the final conclusions, include greater regulation over the handling of personal data, similar to Europe's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) introduced last year.

It also called for new penalties for invasion of privacy and greater controls on merger and acquisition activity by the biggest digital firms.

- Growing power of Big Tech -

One of its most radical suggestions is the creation of an Algorithm Review Board to monitor the complex formulae used to deliver advertisements, and rank news content and referral services to news media.

The ACCC said such a regulator was needed to ensure the big digital players do not "favour their own business interests, through their market power and presence across multiple markets".

"There are also issues with the role of digital platforms in determining what news and information is accessed by Australians, how this information is provided, and its range and reliability."

ACCC chairman Rod Sims has said regulatory authorities in the United States, Britain, Europe and other areas are closely monitoring the outcome of the Australian inquiry as they all mull possible responses to the growing power of tech titans.

Prime Minister Scott Morrison's government has already taken controversial steps targeting Big Tech, including introducing criminal penalties for executives of social media companies which permit the distribution of violent content on their platforms and an unprecedented law forcing tech firms to help security services break encrypted communications.

Tech companies have warned that enacting many of the ACCC's proposed recommendations would be impractical, or lead firms to simply avoid doing business in Australia.

"We obviously need really clear rules for the internet that protect privacy, safety, the economic and social benefits of technology while also protecting competition and innovation," said Sunita Bose, head of the DIGI lobbying group formed by Google, Facebook, Twitter and other firms to deal with Australian regulators.

But, in an interview with Nine media newspapers ahead of the ACCC release, Bose cautioned that some of the watchdog's recommendations, on top of the government's earlier measures, could not only hurt the big players but have an even greater impact on start-ups and smaller firms with limited resources to meet new regulatory demands.

She warned in particular against attempts to monitor and regulate algorithms, which she said "constitute highly sensitive commercial information".

"The prospect of having to disclose such sensitive information will serve as a deterrent to global digital companies and start-ups initiating or expanding their operations in Australia," she said.

GOOGLE

Twitter

urn:contentItem:5WDS-0KS1-JBYT-H296-00000-00Aussie watchdog readies clampdown on Google, Facebook2019-06-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:17:44ZLexisNexisAussie watchdog readies clampdown on Google, FacebookJune 24

June 24 -- Australia's competition watchdog is poised to call for far-reaching new regulations on Facebook, Google and other tech giants which could have global ramifications for how they make money and choose the content people consume.


The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's recommendations, if confirmed, would be among the strongest yet in a drive to rein in the power of digital behemoths amid a host of worldwide concerns ranging from anti-trust issues to privacy abuse, and their role in spreading disinformation and hateful content.
'Critical point' Following an 18-month inquiry into the power of digital platforms, the ACCC is due to issue its final report by June 30. It is expected to include proposals for sweeping controls over tech companies' handling of personal data and their use of "opaque" algorithms to rank how they display advertisements, search results and content.
In a 328-page preliminary report issued in December, the ACCC had raised alarm over the "substantial" market power wielded by the likes of Google and Facebook, and notably the "lack of transparency" in their operations.
"We are at a critical point in considering the impact of digital platforms on society," said the report, initiated by the conservative government at the behest of Australia's main media organisations.
The report focused particular attention on the huge impact Google and Facebook have had on Australia's news industry, with the number of newspaper and online journalists falling more than 20 per cent since 2014 as digital advertising revenues were overwhelmingly captured by the two tech titans.
"While the ACCC recognises their significant benefits to consumers and businesses, there are important questions to be asked about the role the global digital platforms play in the supply of news and journalism in Australia," it said.
Possible proposals A set of preliminary proposals set out in the report, many of which are expected to figure in the final conclusions, include greater regulation over the handling of personal data, similar to Europe's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) introduced last year. It also called for new penalties for invasion of privacy and greater controls on merger and acquisition activity by the biggest digital firms.
One of its most radical suggestions is the creation of an Algorithm Review Board to monitor the complex formulae used to deliver advertisements, and rank news content and referral services to news media.
The ACCC said such a regulator was needed to ensure the big digital players do not "favour their own business interests, through their market power and presence across multiple markets. There are also issues with the role of digital platforms in determining what news and information is accessed by Australians, how this information is provided, and its range and reliability."
ACCC chairman Rod Sims has said regulatory authorities in the United States, Britain, Europe and other areas are closely monitoring the outcome of the Australian inquiry as they all mull possible responses to the growing power of tech titans.
Taking on Big Tech Prime Minister Scott Morrison's government has already taken controversial steps targeting Big Tech, including introducing criminal penalties for executives of social media companies which permit the distribution of violent content on their platforms and an unprecedented law forcing tech firms to help security services break encrypted communications.
Tech companies have warned that enacting many of the ACCC's proposed recommendations would be impractical, or lead firms to simply avoid doing business in Australia.
"We obviously need really clear rules for the internet that protect privacy, safety, the economic and social benefits of technology while also protecting competition and innovation," said Sunita Bose, head of the DIGI lobbying group formed by Google, Facebook, Twitter and other firms to deal with Australian regulators.
But, in an interview with Nine media newspapers ahead of the ACCC release, Bose cautioned that some of the watchdog's recommendations, on top of the government's earlier measures, could not only hurt the big players but have an even greater impact on start-ups and smaller firms with limited resources to meet new regulatory demands.
She warned in particular against attempts to monitor and regulate algorithms, which she said "constitute highly sensitive commercial information". "The prospect of having to disclose such sensitive information will serve as a deterrent to global digital companies and start-ups initiating or expanding their operations in Australia," she said.

Tech companies have warned that enacting many of the ACCC's proposed recommendations would be impractical, or lead firms to simply avoid doing business in Australia.

"We obviously need really clear rules for the Internet that protect privacy, safety, the economic and social benefits of technology while also protecting competition and innovation," said Sunita Bose, head of the DIGI lobbying group formed by Google, Facebook, Twitter and other firms to deal with Australian regulators.

But, in an interview with Nine media newspapers ahead of the ACCC release, Bose cautioned that some of the watchdog's recommendations, on top of the government's earlier measures, could not only hurt the big players but have an even greater impact on start-ups and smaller firms with limited resources to meet new regulatory demands.

She warned in particular against attempts to monitor and regulate algorithms, which she said "constitute highly sensitive commercial information".

"The prospect of having to disclose such sensitive information will serve as a deterrent to global digital companies and startups initiating or expanding their operations in Australia," she said.

urn:contentItem:5RXH-MP61-DXH2-61DF-00000-00Austin Bombing Suspect Kills Himself With Explosive Device; Congressional Spending Bill Will Include $2.8 Billion To Battle Opioid Addiction; President Trump Is Expected To Unveil Heavy Tariffs On China By Friday2018-03-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:17:44ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTKevin McCarthy, Brian Murphy, Mariano Rivera, Heather Zumarraga, James HoffaNEWSFinancial032103cb.231Austin Bombing Suspect Kills Himself With Explosive Device; Congressional Spending Bill Will Include $2.8 Billion To Battle Opioid Addiction; President Trump Is Expected To Unveil Heavy Tariffs On China By FridayMaria Bartiromo, Todd Piro, Jon Hilsenrath, Dagen McDowell, Stuart Varney, Nicole Petallides, Lauren Simonetti, Adam Shapiro

REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CA), HOUSE MAJORITY LEADER: -- they worked together from ATF, FBI and the local law enforcement. And they really -- I think in a nature tracked this down rather quickly because it was a difficult situation to deal with. I feel for all those in Austin, how scared they must have been in the process but I think they're taking a right approach, how they approached them but also from the standpoint of making sure they are correct, there's nothing else out there.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes.

(CROSSTALK)

MCCARTHY: And learn more as it goes on.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. I mean, at this point they're saying look, stay vigilant, we don't know the motive, we don't know if this individual did this alone or if there are others involved.

MCCARTHY: Yes. And you don't know -- I think when they get to their house, looking through it, I don't know if it's going to be booby trap but they'll have much more information. That's interesting if there's not somebody else involved in these type of situations. So, we'll have to look and see.

BARTIROMO: Let me move on and ask you about the spending bill, what you're working on this week. We'll we see a government shutdown? It appears you've agreed on a top line number but are going through details, where are we?

MCCARTHY: Well, you know, the last battle was really the big battle because the battle was always for about and what funding will we go the future with. Military needs the resource and this is going to be the greatest increase for the military in about the last decade because they needed the increase of where we're going. You get a pay raise for the troops but importantly, the investment that has been cut for so many years to keep us up especially when you looking at North Korea, Russia, and others, we have to be able to make that investment going forward. It's just finishing up the details. I believe we'll finish today, post something and then be able to vote in the next day or two.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you about that because Reuters is reporting that it will include nearly $1.6 billion for border security. Is that true?

MCCARTHY: I believe at the end of the day no final details but that's a -- that's what we put in prior when we pass the appropriation bills and 1.6 is the number I would like to see. The President had made another offer. I mean, this is where the President is trying to solve this DACA situation. Think about how many times he has reached out to the Democrats and I think he found some common ground but then again they said no, he would extend out DACA for a number of years. If you finish the border security. The Democrats said they did not want to do that but I give the President great deal amount of credit to try and to solve this issue.

BARTIROMO: Why don't they want to do it? I mean, the truth is is that he put a deal on the table that was even better than they were initially asking for.

MCCARTHY: It was. He is looking for border security and making sure that you don't come back to this two years from now but he extended it further for the number of individuals to be able to go there. If I were the Democrats knowing what they want, I would have taken that deal. Sometimes I wonder some of them want to just keep a problem out there. Almost make it political instead of solving a problem.

BARTIROMO: Going into the midterms they want something to attack the President on.

MCCARTHY: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Let me ask you about the opioid spending because the last time we were talking about a spending bill there was a lot of complaints and criticism about too much spending. I recognize you need to give to get in terms of the military but is it including 2.8 billion in opioid spending and what are other spending that perhaps you're going to have to swallow as a result of getting what you need for the military?

MCCARTHY: Look, the main reason we are -- where we currently are because it takes 60 votes in the Senate. So, if we didn't have to have that, we would be in a different situation. But if you wanted to be able about to plus up the military, actually bring the military back, think about how many planes are not able about to fly, think about the number of military men and women who have actually died in accidents just in the last year. So we all knew we had to have that investment, but to get the investment in the military, the Democrats held us to appoint that we had to invest domestically. But think about where we put that domestic money. We're putting almost three billion into opioids, we're putting a number of billion into infrastructure and that's the part that we've been working out directing with. In the last Congress we had the CARA bill dealing with the opioid but you're having almost 175 people a year die, brother and sisters from the standpoint of -- for this opioid epidemic and it's got to stop.

BARTIROMO: Yes. All right. Let me -- let me switch gears and ask you about the trade restraints that we're expecting to come out of this White House tomorrow. What can you tell us about these measures? There's been a lot of criticism and upset over the aluminum and steel tariffs. Now we understand that the White House will come up with tariffs on imports of at least $30 billion and also restrictions in terms of Chinese investments in the United States.

MCCARTHY: Well, I actually think this is where the President is correct looking at China, looking at the intellectual property. The -- what they have been one stealing from America, what they've been going in in buying and taking back to China dealing with military, dealing with technology and others. I think it's an area that you're going to get a get a lot of agreement on. And when you look at the steel and aluminum, remember, the President gave flexibility on that. So, what was first brought out and what ended up at the end of the day when we get the majority of our steel from Canada, that had an exemption in it as well. So, I think what you'll find coming out, there will be an opportunity but I think he is correct about looking at what China has been doing and what China has been stealing from America. I think you're going to find other countries join in with us as well.

BARTIROMO: The President said that he wants to open this up to industry. He wants to hear from companies in terms of what products should be really targeted most. How will that process take place?

MCCARTHY: Well, he will lay out the framework coming forward but I think this is a positive aspect. He's not just going in and saying one-size- fits-all. He wants to listen to individuals and then go out and lead and make sure it's right. It's correct to have this challenge with China. We don't want to get into a trade war but what we have watched China do over a number of years, they use from state control going in and buying companies bringing the technology back to China, they stole a number of different intellectual properties from numerous companies and it's not just in one field, it will go down to agriculture, it will go into all different aspects. So I think standing up and putting a different perspective on this will turn out to be a very positive aspect.

BARTIROMO: Because people get this particularly industry because when you want to have business in China sell to the 1.3 billion people. China forces you to give up the technology to a do so, right? And then you can't even have an ownership of anything, full ownership, it's a joint venture and you only own 49 percent.

MCCARTHY: They have you come in 49 percent, they learn what you're doing and a few short years they kick you away and they have it all. And they come in numerous times what we've watched and be able to leapfrog of taking the technology and not paying for it. I think it has to stop. People have to respect intellectual property that people invest in and I think that's one of the greatest strengths of America but you're not going to out innovating if they keep stealing the property.

BARTIROMO: So do you want to see a reciprocal situation there whereas China can't out-and-out acquire companies here that it's 49 percent joint venture. I mean, is that the kind of a reciprocal situation that may come out of this?

MCCARTHY: Well, I don't want to see just one size fits all.

BARTIROMO: OK.

MCCARTHY: But I want something to be fair in the process. And the other aspect you look at there's other things that happen with this. As the President stands up to China, China realizes they've done something wrong and now they're finding standing up to North Korea. It's changing the outcome of other aspects. The reason North Korea is coming to the stable, wanted a sanction but I think a part of what -- how the President led not only here but standing up tough to China at the same time and realize there is a new sheriff in town and the world is going to be a little different in this administration.

BARTIROMO: You're right. It's true. Let me ask you about the number here because The Washington Post is saying, look, this is $60 billion in imports. The Wall Street Journal is saying $30 billion in imports. Do you have any sense? What is the real number?

MCCARTHY: Well, I think if the President is going to sit and listen to the industry, I don't think anybody has the number I get. So people will throw numbers out there but if he's going to sit and listen to the industry which I think he should do, takes their input and let's put the very best plan forward, that's a good way going about handling it.

BARTIROMO: I know for a long time, China has certain industries that are off limits, it doesn't matter who it is. If a foreigner comes in, wants to acquire defense company in China, it's not going to happen. Same with financial services, should we have industries that are off limits?

MCCARTHY: Well, I think there are certain areas we should look about off limits and that is stealing the technology especially if it's going into military and others. And when you look at these mergers and acquisitions that China has been doing, state run, going in and stealing these different things, to me, that is an aspect that we really have to look seriously (INAUDIBLE) be able to do it but I think we have to take a new approach.

BARTIROMO: The President has also talked about a phase two of the tax plan, he referred to that, that with Kevin Brady recently. Will Democrats really get onboard with the phase two of cutting taxes?

MCCARTHY: They didn't get onboard with phase one.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

MCCARTHY: Remember, they said this will be armageddon that the bonuses were crumbs but think about how much this tax plan has done. 1.2 million Americans got a longer maternity leave in one company. Millions of Americans got bonuses, there are electrical bill, here we are going to have snow coming, it's actually lower because they passed on the tax cuts in the utility companies. But Democrats still said no, they came out with their own plan. They want to raise taxes if they were able to take the majority. So, I think it's smart. All the benefit that we had where you have unemployment at a new low, I think it's smart that we look at another tax plan going forward to be -- have more tax cuts be able to move this economy and growth. If you really want to get out of this debt, yes, you have to curve the spending in government but you have to grow the economy. You will not get out of this problem without growth. And look at all conversations that you had, we're finally getting back to three percent growth. Something we didn't see in the last eight years.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCCARTHY: It's a new administration, it's a new opportunity for America and I think it's the beginning of America's comeback.

BARTIROMO: What do you want to see in phase two? Would that be making the individual cuts permanent? Would that be another cut on small businesses. What specifically would you like to see in phase two?

MCCARTHY: Well, of course I want to see the individuals made permanent. But like any big bill when you go through it, there are going to be other aspects that you didn't think about. Let's see where we need to go there. Let's see how this bill has transferred and changed the economy because there are places we missed. Let's listen to the economy and let's go back and analyze that.

BARTIROMO: I'll tell you, now we're talking about four percent growth, potentially in this year or perhaps in '19. Do you worry that any of this growth story which obviously is a big reason coming from the tax plan is going to get impacted by these tariffs. I mean, that's the worry that in fact if you were to pull these aluminum and steel tariffs in place which are supposed to get implement beginning this week, Friday that maybe takes away from some of this growth.

MCCARTHY: Well, I'm worried about doing anything that's harming this growth going forward and that's why I was happy that the President had some exemptions in there especially when it comes to our allies and others.

BARTIROMO: That's a big part of the story.

MCCARTHY: I mean, China makes the most aluminum and the most steel but that's not where we buy it from. And they're subsidizing it. So is there another way of going about doing it, not harming our allies? And I think that's the way the exemptions should be moved through but I'm nervous about what happens to this economy. Yes, we are growing, we don't want to harm or slow it down but I also think we have to stand up to China in what they've been doing, that's why I don't think one across the board position works, that's why listening to the industry is probably a very smart way to handle it.

BARTIROMO: You say China makes the most terms of aluminum and steel. That's the overcapacity issue, right? So they produce it and then they just put it into the global marketplace, maybe we get the most from Canada but that doesn't mean ultimately it came from China.

MCCARTHY: Because they'll do the raw material, they'll supply it. Government subsidizes it and able to send it out. And what we've watched but you also see a number of jobs lower down manufacturing have a great deal amount of jobs that utilize that steel to make a product. And you want to make sure those o jobs continue growing.

BARTIROMO: Congressman, I got to ask about Facebook, let's talk about that, the mining controversy. The stock is down again this morning, Facebook officials could meet with aides from the House Judiciary Committee as early as today. We're told CEO Mark Zuckerberg expected to address his staff on Friday. Company coming under fire after Cambridge Analytica allegedly misused private information for more than 50 million Facebook users during the 2016 elections. We spoke with Chris Collins earlier, your colleague from New York and he was pretty adamant in terms of what he is expecting. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. CHRIS COLLINS (R), NEW YORK: I'm confident you will see new legislation coming out and/or the enforcement where it belongs, the FTC will be coming down on them, so that it's more evident for someone that you're checking a box it's OK.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: What should be done here? What can Congress do at this point?

MCCARTHY: Well, Congress can do a lot of things but I don't want to Congress to overreact without having all the information. First thing I want Congress to do is learn everything that happened. But this is a technology that's continued to grow. This is where a lot of people get their information even though it may not be true information. So what roles do we see that should change in there? The first thing that has to happen is Facebook needs to come and talk to Congress, they need to answer the questions. And after we get all the information, we should see what's appropriate and what's appropriate for the future for the individual going forward. But people you sponsoring ads. Do people know who is paying for these ads? People are putting misinformation out there and utilizing Facebook to disrupt the election process. People have to understand that and there may be safeguards that we have to deal with but I don't want to prejudge without having all the information.

BARTIROMO: I'm not -- I'm not surprised that the political part of this story uses and mines all of this data. Isn't that what happened during the election of Barack Obama when he was masterful in terms of mining data and figuring out where potential voters were.

MCCARTHY: You know what? They were so good, they put it out there for people to see and they sold it around the world for other campaigns to use. The U.K. used it in the process. They were the ones that pretty much started this. And the difference was, the valley was very excited to help Barack Obama. It's a different aspect now but we want to make sure that your privacy is protected but every action you take on Facebook, if you like something, somebody can mine that, right? If you put up from some emotion or some campaign you want to support, people mine that and know which direction you're going. I don't know that that's wrong but we want to make sure people understand that and know that going in that your privacy is protected but also your actions are known.

BARTIROMO: I would imagine today given the powerful position and influence that these companies have, you have to look at this.

MCCARTHY: Oh, by far. We have to seriously look at this because Facebook is more than a place that somebody goes to post their pictures of their family vacation, right? Now people are getting their news from it, they're posting content on it. And they can't sit there and live in today's world with the laws that they had in the past. I think you have to modernize and you have to apply the traditions to a changing future at the same time.

BARTIROMO: Congressman, great information from this morning. Thanks so much.

MCCARTHY: Thank you for having me.

BARTIROMO: And it's great that you're working through this snowstorm.

MCCARTHY: Yes. Government may be shut down but Congress is not, we will still vote.

BARTIROMO: We like it. Thank you. Kevin McCarthy joining us. We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Let's get right to the breaking news out of Texas this morning where the suspect in a series of Austin area bombings is now dead after killing himself with an explosive device as police closed in on him. Todd Piro is live on the ground in Round Rock this morning with the very latest. Todd, good morning to you. What can you tell us?

TODD PIRO, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Maria, good morning to you. The sun is coming up now, but this really is a continuation of a really long night and even longer month for the individuals behind me here at the scene. ATF, fire department, ambulances, police officers from Austin P.D. and of course the FBI, the scene right behind me is where the 24-year-old suspect blew himself up earlier this morning following what were some amazing events last night. Police had been following a number of leads but in the last 24 to 36 hours, their main person of interest turned into a suspect.

A lot of that was due to those FedEx packages which had a lot of information in them and on them that cops were able to piece together. They're able to figured out that he was driving a particular car which led them to a hotel where he was staying. Police then surrounded that hotel overnight and were waiting for tactical teams to arrive in order to make the make scene as safe as possible. Car started to drive away, police started follow, the car then stopped as SWAT approached, the suspect blew up the car and died in the blast. That's how we got there but when I spoke with the mayor of Austin earlier, he said it really could not have been done without the help of his community. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVE ADLER, MAYOR OF AUSTIN, TEXAS: Our community has rallied, you know, the only job we have was to be a little bit more vigilant, to notice things that were suspicious or out of place. And we were all doing that as a community and I think as the facts coming out the community is going to see that that actually helped resolve this.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

PIRO: But Maria, while a new day is done and there is a sense of relief here throughout Texas. Two things to keep in mind, one, we do not yet know if the individual, the suspect who died had any accomplices and two, we also don't know if there are any packages out there in the community. So please remain, vigilant if you see something doesn't seem right call the authorities, there are so many of them working on scene right now trying to make sure that we can put this situation behind us. Maria, back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Todd. Thank you very much. Todd Piro in Texas. Coming up. Former Major League Baseball all-star pitcher Mariano Rivera joins us. He will explain his new role in combating the opioid crisis in America, he is next. Then General Mills beats third-quarter earnings in revenue expectations, due in part the strong demand for snacks in North American. We break down the numbers coming up. And check futures as well. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We just heard from Kevin McCarthy that the Congressional spending bill will include $2.8 billion to battle opioid addiction. Now there's a new tool in the fight against growing crises. For many people opioids are the only thing that can help their physical pain but what if a nondrug would be able to combat that pain? One company has developed a wearable ultrasound that treats chronic and acute pain.

One of the greatest pitchers in baseball history is a supporter, joining us right now is Brian Murphy, NanoVibronix CEO and Mariano Rivera, former Major League all-star pitcher. Good to see you, gentlemen. Thank you so much for joining us.

BRIAN MURPHY, CEO, NANOVIBRONIX: Thank you.

MARIANO RIVERA, FORMER MAJOR LEAGUE ALL-STAR PITCHER: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: So Brian, kick us off here, you brought one of the wearables. Can you show us how it works, tell us about it, NanoVibronix.

MURPHY: It's actually NanoVibronix. We're a medical device company. Recently up listed to NASDAQ. And we employ a technology and all of our products called surface acoustic wave, the technology is basically wearable ultrasound or low-level, low-frequency ultrasound. And we employ at -- into a product called PainShield which provides resolution to pain, the cause of the pain rather than just masking the pain.

BARTIROMO: I see. Mariano, tell us your history with pain, how you got introduced to NanoVibronix.

RIVERA: Maria, first of all, I mean, I got into this with my friend Paul (Bucker) and I tell you what, I got into this because my wife was have a little back problem and I asked my friend to provide me one of those devices and I was able to use it on her and she got better. But I tell you one thing though, Maria, I wouldn't have this when I was playing baseball. I might would have played another three, four years.

BARTIROMO: Wow. So you -- so you've seen it and used, it works, that's why you're supporting it. I understand you spoken about this with President Trump?

RIVERA: Definitely I have to (INAUDIBLE) it's -- I mean, the President fighting opioids and this is one of the alternatives. You know, we fight on opioids but we don't have what we're going to do after that, so I mean, the best thing is using a product that is safe and it's handy. So, we have to move towards alternative.

JON HILSENRATH, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: Mariano, you say you would have played another three, four years. That's a lot more stage than you already had. What kind of pain were you experiencing late in your career and what is this product -- what did this product do to help you?

RIVERA: Well, more so than pain, it's soreness basically, I mean, after your -- in your career and activities, kind of like minimize but once you're more active, you got back pain, knee pain, all kind of pains. And this device is amazing. So I mean, I truly believe that it's something that we can take a look, and start using it.

BARTIROMO: Yes, Dagen, jump in here because the truth is is when you're talking about opioids, there is such an addiction that people -- that they get worse -- they get into a worse situation because you take the opioid, you want more and then people have gone on to heroin.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Right. Because it -- opioids quite frankly are expensive so they turn to other similar drugs. Brian, I want to know though that with this device, what type of pain does it treat that opioids would also be used to treat because there -- when you say pain that is a catchall, a never pain is very different from bone pain, very different from muscle pain. So what kind of pain does this device specifically treat?

MURPHY: We actually just completed a study, something called trigeminal neuralgia, it's a facial nerve pain that's also called the suicide pain. There is only really two interventions for it. One is opioids and the other is severing the nerve in the face, not good alternatives. The earlier studies showed that it was very effective on treatment, long-term resolution of trigeminal neuralgia. So we figured if we could solve that problem which is the most horrendous type of pain that only opioids can cover up. Everything else is pretty much a walk in the park. Many sports injuries, tennis elbow, should injury, neck injury.

MCDOWELL: Tendinitis-related pain.

MURPHY: Exactly. Any soft tissue type of injury.

MCDOWELL: That's incredible.

BARTIROMO: Yes. It really is. It's terrific to see the support. Mariano, did you mention this specific product to the President?

RIVERA: For how (INAUDIBLE) this is a conversation that we need to have, you know, because I mean, that's what we need to move towards. There's equipment that can be helpful and not hurting the people. And that's exactly what we need.

BARTIROMO: We will leave it there. Mariano Rivera, great to have you on the show. Brian Murphy, you as well. Thanks very much for joining us, gentlemen.

MURPHY: Thank you, Maria.

RIVERA: Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: We'll see you soon. Thank you. Coming up. President Trump response to the series of bombings in Austin. His response next. And then Teamsters President, James Hoffa will join me in an exclusive Fox Business interview. He weighs in on the President's trade restraints on China and a lot more. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Breaking news this morning, the Austin bombing suspect is dead after a confrontation with police overnight. Authorities say that the 24-year-old male suspect killed himself after detonating an explosive device inside of his car as the police approached the car. Police have not yet uncovered a motive. Adam Shapiro was live at the White House this morning with the latest on how the administration is reacting to this investigation. Adam, good morning to you.

ADAM SHAPIRO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: And a good morning to you, Maria. The President actually tweeted this morning about what's happened in Austin. Let me give you the actual tweet that the President put out, he said, "AUSTIN BOMBING SUSPECT IS DEAD," in all capital letters. "Great job by law enforcement and all concerned." Now, remember just yesterday on camera, the President had been talking about what was going on in Austin and the investigation. There were some 500 federal law enforcement personnel working with local law enforcement to try and find the suspect who they believed may be the man they're now identifying. But the President yesterday said, this is obviously a very, very sick individual or maybe individuals. These are sick people and we will get to the bottom of it. We will be very strong.

So, as you have said, they are trying to make sure there's no one else involved in this. There is a man who is the suspect who is believed to have committed suicide by blowing himself up. And the President has tweeted this morning, "Great job by law enforcement and all concerned." Maria, back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Adam, thank you so much, Adam Shapiro. Now, we want to go to the latest in China and the tariff turmoil. President Trump is set to unveil tariffs on Chinese imports by the end of the week as you heard here first, have been reporting that something is coming against China, whether restrictions on trade or tariffs. Reports say now that the price range is between $30 billion and $60 billion of imports. The tariffs are expected to target technology, telecommunications, and intellectual property. This comes just a few days before the controversial steel and aluminum tariffs are set to go into effect. The Wall Street Journal is reporting that China is ready to square off and deliver counter tariffs of its own. Joining me right now in a Fox Business exclusive is International Brotherhood of Teamsters President, James P. Hoffa. James, it's good to have you.

JAMES P. HOFFA, PRESIDENT, INTERNATIONAL BROTHERHOOD OF TEAMSTERS: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. You're happy with tariffs?

HOFFA: We are. You know, this is -- we've had tremendous dumping here. We've had 30 steel companies go out of business. We need steel, we need aluminum to have our national security, and this is a deliberate dumping by China, Vietnam, whoever can do it, and they keep sending it here. We've got to stop it, and this is the way to basically level the playing field.

BARTIROMO: Why do you say the dumping is an issue for the unions, for workers, why, explain, connect the dots for us?

HOFFA: It's very simple. Your 30 companies are out of business. These people have lost their jobs, because of a plan by China to keep dumping their -- they're creating an excess of supply out there, and dumping it here, we've got to stop that. It's protect American jobs, that's what this is about.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and the issue though is that we're going to receive retaliation. I mean, there was a speculation earlier that Europe is going to institute a 25 percent tariff. Do you want to get into a trade war?

HOFFA: Well, you know, the answer is it's going to level out. I think we've got to negotiate with people to say, hey, let's find a way to get this done, whether it's China or whether it's that. This is basically a shot across their bow to say we've got a problem here, you've got to stop. If you stop, we can start working it out, especially with our allies with Germany, France with regard to the U.K. If there is a problem, we're going to put these on you. Let's work backyards and find out how do we solve these problems, but we have to start somewhere. This is a shot across the bow, I think it's a good idea.

BARTIROMO: It's interesting that you say it's a good idea. Typically, the unions have gone with the Democrats but you like what this President is doing economically.

HOFFA: He's doing the right thing with regard to the trade. We're also working on NAFTA, we're working on basically the tariffs. These are things that have to be done that no one had the guts to do it. But you go back a little bit, don't forget, I think Reagan did something like that with Harley-Davidson. This has been done before and we need more of this right now. There's a national emergency right now to protect American jobs, right now. We need steel for national security, we need aluminum, we have to have strong, strong companies here, and the way that it's going, we're not going to have any steel companies left. So, this is a beginning of something to save American jobs and to protect national security.

BARTIROMO: James, let's talk about NAFTA for a moment, you mentioned NAFTA. It's still up in the air, negotiating between the U.S., Mexico, and Canada, what do you want to see? What's most important in terms of a change in the NAFTA legislation?

HOFFA: Well, the big thing with NAFTA -- you know, Canada, really, is not that much of a problem, because their lifestyle and their standards are basically the same as ours. But when you get to Mexico, you have such a disparity with regard to the standard of living and the wages. It's become a dumping ground and corporations are moving there, building factories, shipping back over here, taking advantage of cheap labor. We've got to stop that, we got to have a strong labor chapter, you have to have stronger unions down there. We've got to change the way it's going down there. It's not happening, we're not seeing -- this is 25 years of NAFTA and we haven't seen their standard of living go up like it has everywhere else. That's what got to be addressed. So, we have to have a strong labor chapter, we've got to do, you know, different things have already been done, we're protecting the border from unsafe Mexican trucks. We're on the right path, and we're working very closely with Ambassador Lighthizer who is doing a great job, and we're going to have a NAFTA we can all be proud of.

BARTIROMO: So, you want to see border protection?

HOFFA: Absolutely. Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I mean, the President is trying to get the money for the border wall but he is facing pushback from the Dems.

HOFFA: Well, the border wall is something different than basically have unsafe Mexican trucks. But you know, some type of protection, we have to have a border -- I do believe --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: -- he wants to protect the southern border.

HOFFA: I do believe we have to have borders. And I think that, you know, I'm not -- I'm not a legal immigration back-and-forth is fine. I don't have any problem with that.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And you're not afraid to say it.

HOFFA: No.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HOFFA: Right. Let's do it.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you about this pension push, school teachers and union members pushing to preserve their pensions after the fate remains unclear and the $1.3-trillion spending bill on Capitol Hill last week, bipartisan committee met for the first time in Washington to address this pension crisis. We know where the money is being spent and where the growth is, and it is in those entitlements.

HOFFA: Well, that's not really true. We just gave $1.3-trillion gift to big business. I mean, there's a lot of money they just gave away, so they can't say, oh, we don't have any money now.

BARTIROMO: Are you talking about the tax plan?

HOFFA: Yes, you shouldn't have given it away. Now, that it's gone, you're saying, oh, my gosh, $1.3 trillion gone.

BARTIROMO: No, they were lowering --

HOFFA: And so, (INAUDIBLE) there's no money for anybody else. But (INAUDIBLE)

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: They lowered corporate taxes to enable corporations to feel there was an environment out there that they could hire more workers. Are you saying you wanted to see the corporate tax rate of 35 percent stay in place? Is that what you're saying, James?

HOFFA: I would say we should, yes, because these corporations are making - -

BARTIROMO: You wanted a corporate tax rate of 35 percent?

HOFFA: These corporations are making billions of dollars. And now, we're going to say we've got to cut the safety net, we got to get rid of Social Security? Do you -- food stamps? Are you kidding me? Are we really that bad we're going to do that to this country? No, let's get back to the pension. The pension issue which you mentioned, that's an important issue. For the first time, Congress is focused on the issue of pension, the pension crisis, we have joint committees set up right now to start working on this problem. Orrin Hatch has made the right comments about what we have to do to address the pension crisis in America, and we're going to have a solution by November, and I'm very proud of what they've done. We've had input into it. We're working with Congress, both Republicans and Democrats, to address this problem. It's a major problem, we need money to fix the problem, the answer is, people can't work 40 years, promised a pension and then pull the rug on them, that's wrong, people deserve pensions.

BARTIROMO: Well, the truth is that these programs are going out of -- I mean, they are -- they are going bankrupt, right? You see Medicare, Medicaid, Social Security. Those programs are going bankrupt in the next 15 to 20 years, even less than that.

HOFFA: Well, if you -- if you give $1.5 trillion away, they'll go bankrupt because there's no money. The answer is you have to fund everything. American is getting grayer, we're going to have more people on Social Security. What are you going to say, we're not going to have Social Security? You'll have a revolution in this country. People have been promised this. I know thousands of people that depend on Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid. That is what this country is about. They deserve it, it's working, it's one plan that really does work, the check comes every month, it's just right. Let's not disturb that right now, and these (INAUDIBLE) people now that these -- you know, these people are starting to say, oh, we got to get rid of the so-called "entitlements." When they say entitlements, they're talking about Social Security. You want to get rid of Social Security, you have a revolution in this country.

BARTIROMO: Yes. No, I understand once you give somebody something, it's hard to take it back. But on the corporate tax rate, when you look at a corporate tax rate of 35 percent in America, versus, 13 percent in Ireland, how is that competitive? I mean, how could the U.S. stay at 35 percent corporate rate when all of so many other countries are at such a lower level, that's why you're losing jobs. As a guy who's protecting so many thousands of people's jobs and fighting for the rights of workers, you have to believe that that wasn't competitive.

HOFFA: I don't believe it. These companies here are making so much money right now. And what did we have, trillions of dollars are offshore. You know, Pfizer has all this money overseas, and all of a sudden, they start bringing it back. They're making money, they know how to get around that. The General Electric with all the billions of dollars they make, they didn't file -- they didn't pay taxes at all. Give me a break.

BARTIROMO: Right, I know that. And that's because they had all those loopholes. But this tax plans took all the loopholes out.

HOFFA: Well, I don't know about that, but they'll find a way. I'm telling you, it was better the other way because we had money in the government. When you take that amount of money out of this system right now, it's basically destroying it, and what does Republicans -- the first thing they say is cut Social Security, that's their answer to everything, get rid of the entitlements.

BARTIROMO: All right. So, what do you have to say -- what do you have to say about now three percent economic growth. We were talking about 1-1/2 percent economic growth in the last 10 years. Now, you're talking about three percent partly due to the tax cut plan.

HOFFA: I hope we have three percent -- I hope we have three percent, four percent, five percent. That's good for America.

BARTIROMO: It doesn't just come out of a hat, James, it's happening --

HOFFA: I'm not so sure about that.

BARTIROMO: It's happening because you're seeing a tax cut plan and anticipation of lower taxes.

HOFFA: Well, this is awful robust economy right now. It's going very, very strong.

BARTIROMO: It sure is partly because of the tax cuts.

HOFFA: Well, we'll see. We'll see what happens. I can't predict what it's going to be, but I got news for you, three percent, four percent, it's good for America, it's good for everybody.

BARTIROMO: It sure is. So, do you think that that kind of growth can sustain, if we go on this path and we continue to see job creation, are you expecting that kind of a growth number?

HOFFA: I don't know. If they put the money back in where there -- what I'm disappointed in, is that all this money is coming back to these corporations and not sharing it with the workers. Right now --

BARTIROMO: Well, what about all these thousand-dollar bonuses, James, are you going to call them crumbs?

HOFFA: Let me tell you a story -- now, let me -- it is crumbs.

BARTIROMO: Oh, come on, give me a break.

HOFFA: Let me tell you a story. They said Wal-Mart people are going to give $1,000. You got to work there 20 years.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HOFFA: 20 years. They're not many people who work 20 years.

BARTIROMO: Not everybody -- not every company who gave out a thousand dollars has any restrictions like that.

HOFFA: Why didn't they give it to everybody? And now, we're seeing these other things, United Airlines, you have to have perfect attendance. Well, lots of luck. I mean, that's not fair. Give the money back. Share the money. This was supposed to be what they were telling everybody, they're telling the media, oh, we're going to share this money, and now they're putting all these things in, you have to have a raffle, you have to have this, you have to have perfect attendance.

BARTIROMO: What's the average salary of union person today? I know it depends on seniority and all that. Will you come up with a number?

HOFFA: It depends. We have people making $100,000 --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: $100,000.

HOFFA: No, it's not average. 75,000.

BARTIROMO: OK. 75,000. So, you're telling me that $75,000 job, they don't want a thousand dollars?

HOFFA: I'm saying I --

BARTIROMO: They look at a thousand dollars as crumbs?

HOFFA: But if they gave it them -- but now they're not. For Disney was supposed to give a thousand dollars, now they put a loophole on, only if you approve the contract. Can you believe they did that? Come on, give the money away. You got it, give it back.

BARTIROMO: All right. Look, you have me at trade, I'm not so sure about the tax plan. I like this conversation, James. It's good to see you.

HOFFA: Always good to see. Bye-bye.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much, James P. Hoffa joining us there. We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Music mogul Jimmy Iovine is stepping back from daily involvement in Apple streaming music business. Nicole Petallides on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with details there, watching this market. Nic, good morning.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. So, it's interesting story because when Apple took over and bought these from $3 billion back in 2014, they accrued all of these great media and music moguls. And now, Jimmy Iovine is the last of the bunch. You know, they already lost Dr. Dre and some of the other executives, Rogers, the Nine Inch Nails frontman, all gone. But here is something about Jimmy Iovine. The thing is that he says now, he wants to spend more time with his family. Well, his shares are fully vested in August, so that's an interesting transition. So, he's moving from his lead role here to a consulting role. He's also brought in things like car-pool karaoke and tried to really make Apple more competitive with Spotify where it's likely to take over Spotify with its U.S.-paid subscribers. You could see Apple is down slightly.

Then we're taking a look at General Mills. This is under pressure today. There's (INAUDIBLE) full-year forecast. They said that the earnings per share are going to growing up to one percent rather than the prior forecast of three to four percent. This is the parent of Yoplait and Cheerios. They are unveiling cost cuts. The CEO says he's disappointed but the truth of the matter is that they've actually faced rising costs and also seen a sharp increase in freight and transportation and commodity costs. In fact, trucking and railroads have hiked their prices. And for one reason is they just don't have enough drivers, and it's hurting U.S. companies like General Mills. So, General Mills under pressure today, down 8.6 percent. Maria?

BARTIROMO: All right, Nic, thank you so much. Facebook is facing the music right here in Washington as the fallout over Cambridge Analytica grows. Joining us now, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney. And Stu, I don't know if you heard my interview with Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy, but we talked about when all of this mining of user data started and it was when we were in the beginning of the election of Barack Obama.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, way back, way back when, that's true. Look, I don't think it's an exaggeration to say that Facebook is in crisis. Now, that's a very big statement because I think that Facebook is the most important communications company in the world. Facebook and other digital companies are money machines, precisely because they sell personal information about us. Our information is sold by these digital companies, if there are restrictions on digital companies, Facebook in particular, restrictions on how they can sell, what they can sell, if there's any restriction like that, then Facebook ceases to be the juggernaut that it is now. I think they're facing a leadership crisis, where is Zuckerberg? Zuckerberg is the company, it's set up to be basically his company. He runs it any which way he likes, and so far, he said nothing. Now, Axios is reporting that he's going to say something in the next 24 hours. I think that's eagerly awaited. I have no idea what he's going to say, but that's a company in crisis, and that's a very big thing to say.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, we'll say this, Congress wants him here in Washington, and they want to ask him about this, and they want answers before they decide on legislation. But it looks like you know, the bite of the regulation is coming for these companies, Stu.

VARNEY: Yes. And they're facing what may become a class action lawsuit. After all, if they played not fast and loose but if they didn't have full control of the information on these 50 million people which was used by a political dirty tricks company, that's a breaking in their agreement with the FTC, I believe, or the -- whatever it is, some regulatory authority.

BARTIROMO: The FTC, Stu, you're absolutely right.

VARNEY: FTC. And that is grounds for a lawsuit. And it could be huge. That's a big deal.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I know you'll have a lot more on this in 10 minutes. We'll see you at the top of the hour, Stu, thanks. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins every day at 9:00 a.m. right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. We've got our panel back, Jon Hilsenrath, Heather is here. We've got additional coverage of the breaking news out of Austin, Texas when we come right back. More details emerging on the bombing suspect. Then, the east coast bracing for another snowstorm, hundreds of flights pre-emptively canceled. The weather forecast on the other side of this break.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The bombing suspect in Austin, Texas is now dead. Lauren Simonetti with all the details in New York. Lauren?

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Maria, police say the suspect was a 24-year-old white male found in the parking lot of a hotel in Round Rock, Texas, just north of Austin. He died after he detonated an explosive device inside his car.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BRIAN MANLEY, CHIEF, AUSTIN POLICE DEPARTMENT: As members of the Austin Police Department SWAT team approached the vehicle, the suspect detonated a bomb inside the vehicle, knocking one of our SWAT officers back, and one of our SWAT officers fired at the suspect as well.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: Police warned people to remain vigilant as they learn more about the suspect's whereabouts over the last 24 hours. Investigators also trying to see if the suspect was working with anybody else. All this comes after a package bomb exploded at a FedEx shipping center near San Antonio yesterday, and another bomb was found inside a package at an Austin FedEx. That device was fortunately intercepted. The four earlier explosions killed two people.

While severe weather for the east coast today, the region getting pounded with winds, snow, coastal flooding. It's the fourth nor'easter in less than three weeks. The storm, as you can see, already dumping wet snow in Maryland. This bus lost control, slid down an embankment into a creek. Fortunately no students were onboard and the driver is not hurt. Air travel is also crippled, thousands and thousands of flights canceled for today, as well as tomorrow. So, check with the airline if you're headed out somewhere.

And there's a storm brewing across the Atlantic as well. The European Union is proposing new taxes on big U.S. tech companies that do business in Europe, including Facebook, Alphabet, and Amazon. Under the proposed rules, these companies would pay an additional three percent of revenue from some of their online services there. The upshot is the digital companies could wind up forking over hundreds of millions of euros more in taxes. Now, in order for the proposals to pass, all 28 E.U. countries as well as European Parliament have to agree. The U.S. has already warned against taxes that are aimed at big tech companies.

Facebook shares in the premarket are now down for the third day in a row, losing over 10 percent of their value in that time. Well, the Federal Reserve widely expected to raise interest rates today. First policy meeting under Fed Chair Jerome Powell. This would also be the first rate hike of the year. Investors looking at if the Fed will raise rates more than the predicted three times this year, of course, Fox Business will have a special coverage of the Fed decision at 2:00 Eastern Time, followed by the first news conference by Jay Powell half an hour after that. Maria?

BARTIROMO: All right. Big news day, Lauren, thank you so much. We've got Jon and Heather with me. We're going to take a quick break and get their thoughts on all of the above. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Final thoughts, Jon Hilsenrath.

HILSENRATH: Two things: the Fed, Jay Powell is on the stage today. And the other thing is watch trade. There's a lot happening on the trade front, including tariffs on China. I think that could be the market mover today, more than the Fed.

HEATHER ZUMARRAGA, VICE PRESIDENT, VISION 4 FUND DISTRIBUTORS: Markets love transparency. Powell is going to give it to him. If he doesn't raise rates, then the markets will sell off.

BARTIROMO: Oh, good point. Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Mark Zuckerberg's New Year's resolution was to fix Facebook. Walk the talk.

BARTIROMO: Good point. Walk the talk. Dagen, thank you. We'll see you again tomorrow, everybody. Here's "VARNEY & COMPANY" and Stuart, take it away.
